questions.question: Match the following theories of the origin of cholesteatoma with their descriptions: 1. Habermann's theory a) Retraction pocket theory 2. Wittmacks theory Ruedi's theory d) Metaplastic theory
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 1-c, 2-a, 3-d, 4-b Explanation: Cholesteatoma is an abnormal growth in the middle ear or mastoid region characterised by the presence of keratinizing squamous epithelium, which is not normally found in these areas. It consists of two main components: (i) a matrix of keratinizing squamous epithelium with a thin fibrous stroma, and (ii) a central mass of keratin debris. Theory Description Congenital theory Presence of congenital cell remnants contributing to cholesteatoma formation. Habermann's theory Epithelial invasion theory Epithelial growth from the outer ear into the middle ear through perforations contributes to cholesteatoma. Wittmaack’s theory Retraction pocket theory Retraction of the tympanic membrane occurs in the attic or posterosuperior pars tensa. Stratified squamous epithelium lines the outer membrane. Invagination forms a retraction pocket, acting as a matrix for keratin buildup. The accumulation of keratin leads to the formation of a cholesteatoma. Sade's theory Metaplastic theory Metaplasia of middle ear mucosa into squamous epithelium due to repeated infections leads to cholesteatoma. Ruedi's theory Basal cell hyperplasia theory Basal cell hyperplasia in the skin's germinal layer leads to keratinizing squamous epithelium formation. Reference: Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 8th Edition, Page 79, 80

questions.question: A 5-year-old child is diagnosed with Congenital cholesteatoma. According to Levenson's criteria, which factor is NOT used to diagnose this condition?

options.A: Whitish mass behind a normal tympanic membrane
options.B: Intact pars flaccida and pars tensa

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Family history of Congenital Cholesteatoma Explanation: The child’s presentation aligns with congenital cholesteatoma , which is diagnosed using Levenson's criteria : Whitish mass visible behind an intact tympanic membrane Intact pars flaccida and pars tensa No history of ear discharge or surgeries Exclusion of conditions such as canal atresia While family history might be relevant in understanding the broader context of congenital conditions, Levenson’s criteria specifically do not use family history as a diagnostic factor for congenital cholesteatoma. Classification of Cholesteatoma Congenital Cholesteatoma Acquired Cholesteatoma Congenital cholesteatoma arises from embryonic epidermal cell rests. It can occur in the middle ear, petrous apex, or cerebellopontine angle. In the middle ear, it presents as a white mass behind an intact tympanic membrane. It causes conductive hearing loss. It may be discovered during routine exams or myringotomy. It can spontaneously rupture, leading to ear discharge similar to chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM). Diagnosed using Levenson's criteria : Presence of a whitish mass behind a normal tympanic membrane; (Option A ruled out) An intact pars flaccida and pars tensa; (Option B ruled out) No previous history of ear discharge or perforation; No prior ear surgeries; (Option D ruled out) Ruling out conditions such as canal atresia, intramembranous cholesteatoma, or giant cholesteatoma. A history of otitis media was not ruled out. Primary Acquired Cholesteatoma Occurs without a history of prior otitis media or a preexisting perforation. Its genesis is attributed to three main theories: (a) Invagination of pars flaccida : Persistent negative pressure causes retraction and accumulation of keratin debris , leading to an expanding cholesteatoma. (b) Basal cell hyperplasia : Proliferation of basal cells in the pars flaccida due to infections results in cholesteatoma formation and attic perforation. (c) Squamous metaplasia : Normal attic epithelium transforms into keratinizing squamous epithelium due to subclinical infections. Secondary Acquired Cholesteatoma Occurs with a preexisting perforation in the pars tensa, often a posterosuperior marginal or large central perforation. Its development is attributed to: (a) Migration of squamous epithelium: Keratinizing squamous epithelium from the external ear or tympanic membrane migrates through the perforation into the middle ear. (b) Metaplasia: Repeated infections cause the middle ear mucosa to transform into keratinizing squamous epithelium through the perforation. Cholesteatoma Research. questions.question: A patient with chronic suppurative otitis media reports that their hearing improves when the ear is discharging compared to when it is dry. Which phenomenon best explains this observation?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Round window shielding effect Explanation: The round window shielding effect explains the improved hearing with ear discharge. The discharge helps maintain phase differential by shielding the round window, counteracting the simultaneous impact of sound waves hitting both the oval and round windows in a dry ear. Round Window Shielding Effect: In the Tubotympanic type of CSOM, hearing loss is characterized by conductive loss that rarely exceeds 50 dB, patients may experience a paradoxical effect where they hear better when there is discharge present in the ear compared to when the ear is dry. This phenomenon is attributed to the "round window shielding effect." The discharge helps maintain a phase differential by shielding the round window, which counteracts the simultaneous impact of sound waves hitting both the oval and round windows in the dry ear. In the dry state, the simultaneous stimulation of these windows can cancel each other out, reducing hearing ability. Cholesteatoma Hearers: Hearing loss is predominantly conductive in individuals with cholesteatoma especially the Atticoantral type of CSOM, though there may be an additional sensorineural component. Hearing ability remains normal if the ossicular chain is intact. However, when a cholesteatoma destroys the ossicles, it may bridge the gap left by the damaged ossicles, potentially allowing hearing to be preserved. (Options A & D ruled out) Post-surgical hearing loss is possible after removing the cholesteatoma, making preoperative counselling crucial to set proper expectations and prepare for potential changes in hearing levels. Ossicular chain erosion (Option C) typically leads to worsening hearing loss rather than improvement with discharge. It is not related to the phenomenon observed with ear discharge. Reference: Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 8th Edition, Page 83, 85

questions.question: Which is the most common site of origin for cholesteatoma?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Prussac's space Explanation: Prussac's space is the most common site of origin for cholesteatomas. The majority of cholesteatomas (82%) arise from the pars flaccida in Prussac's space, where they often expand and cause various complications. Cholesteatomas most commonly originate from the pars flaccida from Prussac’s space (82% of cases). Superior extension : This is the most frequent pattern, where the cholesteatoma expands into Prussac's space, erodes the scutum, and displaces the ossicles medially. (Option B) Inferior extension : Less common but more frequently observed in children. Cholesteatomas originating from the pars tensa account for 18% of cases. (Option D ruled out) Posterosuperior extension : The cholesteatoma extends medial to the incus, pushing the ossicles laterally. Anterior and inferior extension : This pattern is less common. Site of Cholesteatoma Recurrence Sinus tympani: The most common site of recurrence, but not the most common site of origin. (Option A ruled out) Oval window niche : The second most frequent site of recurrence. (Option C ruled out) Tip cells. Supratubal recess Residual cells in the mastoid cavity Facial Recess

questions.question: A 7-year-old child presents with a sensation of fullness. The child also reports occasional hearing loss. On otoscopy, a whitish mass behind the tympanic membrane is seen. Based on the information provided, which of the following is least likely to be a consequence of this patient’s diagnosis?

options.A: Bone destruction due to release of enzymes
options.B: Bone destruction due to pressure necrosis
options.C: Extension into the aditus and mastoid

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Pressure necrosis of the surrounding bone Explanation: This 7-year-old child is diagnosed with Cholesteatoma through clinical symptoms such as smelly discharge, ear fullness, and hearing loss. The current understanding is that cholesteatoma causes bone destruction primarily through enzymatic activity rather than pressure necrosis. This option is thus least likely to be a direct consequence based on the revised theory. Properties of Cholesteatoma Path of invasion : Cholesteatoma invades surrounding structures by following the path of least resistance and enzymatic bone destruction. Attic cholesteatoma : May extend backwards into the aditus, antrum, and mastoid; downwards into the mesotympanum; and medially to surround the incus and/or head of the malleus. (Option C ruled out) Bone destruction : Cholesteatoma can destroy ear ossicles, and erode the bony labyrinth, canal of the facial nerve, sinus plate, and tegmen tympani. (Option D ruled out) Enzymes involved : Destruction is attributed to enzymes like collagenase, acid phosphatase, and proteolytic enzymes, which are released by osteoclasts and mononuclear inflammatory cells. (Option A ruled out) Revised theory : Bone destruction is now understood to be due to enzymatic activity rather than pressure necrosis. (Option B) Clinical Findings of Cholesteatoma: Smelly discharge: Often pus-like, coming from the ear. Pressure or fullness in the ear. Dizziness Recurrent ear infections Hearing loss or tinnitus Reference: Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 8th Edition, Page. 80, 81

questions.question: Which is the correct order of ossicular erosion in cholesteatoma , from most common to least common?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Incus > Stapes > Malleus Explanation: The incus is the most commonly eroded ossicle, with the long/lenticular process being the most frequently damaged part. The stapes is the second most commonly affected. The malleus is the least commonly damaged ossicle. Common sites of Ossicular Erosion (Option B, C & D ruled out) Incus: The most commonly damaged part is the long/ Lenticular process. The second most common damage is the body. Stapes: Second most common type of damage. Erosion of the superstructure is more common than total loss. Malleus: Least common damage. Most common bony erosions in the middle ear: Scutum: Most frequently eroded. Lateral attic wall: Also commonly eroded. Incus: Most eroded ossicle in the middle ear. Reference: Ossicular Erosion in Patients Requiring Surgery for Cholesteatoma - PMC Evaluation of Temporal Bone Cholesteatoma - PMC

questions.question: A 45 year out female presents with persistent ear discharge, hearing loss, and a feeling of fullness in the ear. Upon examination, the otolaryngologist performs an otoscopic examination, which reveals an abnormal growth in the ear canal. Which diagnostic test is most useful for assessing the extent of her condition and guiding surgical planning?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) High-resolution CT Explanation: Based on the symptoms described-persistent ear discharge, hearing loss, a feeling of fullness in the ear, and the finding of abnormal growth in the ear canal, the most probable diagnosis is a cholesteatoma. High-resolution CT (HRCT) is critical for assessing the severity of the cholesteatoma, evaluating any osseous damage, and aiding in surgical planning. HRCT provides detailed imaging of bony structures and helps identify the extent of the cholesteatoma. Investigations for cholesteatoma: Otoscopic Examination: Direct inspection of the eardrum using otoscopy, video-otoscopy, otomicroscopy, or video-telescopy. Radiological Examination: CT Scan : Primary imaging technique to assess disease severity, osseous damage, and malformations. High-resolution CT (HRCT) is often used before surgery. MRI : Provides detailed tissue distinction with different pulse sequences. Cholesteatomas typically appear hyperintense on T2WI and hypointense/isointense on T1WI. Tympanometric and Audiometric Tests: Assess hearing loss; audiometry identifies conductive deficiencies. Rinne’s and Weber's tests differentiate between conductive and sensorineural hearing loss. Cholesteatoma is diagnosed using a combination of otoscopic examination, CT, MRI, and ancillary tests like tympanometry and audiometry. Video-Otoscopy (Option A) is useful for visualizing the ear canal and eardrum directly but does not provide detailed information on the extent of disease or bony structures. Rinne Test (Option C) is an audiometric test used to differentiate between conductive and sensorineural hearing loss but does not provide information on the extent of cholesteatoma or guide surgical decisions. Diffusion-weighted MRI (Option D) helps detect recurrence or residual cholesteatoma, particularly after surgery, but HRCT is the primary imaging tool for pre-surgical assessment of the disease extent. Reference: Diagnosis and Treatment Modalities of Cholesteatomas: A Review - PMC

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the treatment of cholesteatoma is false?

options.A: Canal Wall Down Mastoidectomy involves removing of posterior canal wallto create an open cavity.
options.B: Tympanoplasty for cholesteatoma repair may use synthetic prostheses to repair the ossicles.
options.C: William Wilde's incision is made approximately 3 cm in front of the ear.
options.D: Canal Wall Up Mastoidectomy involves preserving the posterior canal wall.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) William Wilde's incision is made approximately 3 cm in front of the ear. surgery. Treatment of Cholesteatoma Surgery : The primary treatment for cholesteatoma is surgery, typically involving: Mastoidectomy : Removal of disease from the mastoid bone, which may involve: Canal Wall Down (Radical Mastoidectomy) : Removing all bony walls to create an open cavity. (Option A ruled out) Canal Wall Up (Closed Cavity Mastoidectomy) : Preserving bony partitions. (Option D ruled out) William Wilde's incision: A curved incision behind the ear, approximately 1 cm from and parallel to the retroauricular sulcus behind the ear, starting at the top where the pinna attaches to the mastoid tip. (Option C) MacEwen’s triangle (suprameatal triangle): The mastoid antrum is revealed here. Tympanoplasty : Repair of the eardrum using grafts of cartilage or fascia; damaged ossicles may be repaired with natural bone, cartilage, or synthetic prostheses. (Option B ruled out) Procedure Details : Surgery is delicate and usually takes 2 to 3 hours. Patients often go home the same day. Complete removal of cholesteatoma is crucial to prevent regrowth; regular follow-up is essential, and sometimes a second surgery may be needed.

questions.question: A patient with cholesteatoma is considering surgical options. Which of the following is a characteristic of a canal wall-up procedure compared to a canal wall-down procedure?

options.A: Requires regular cleaning of the mastoid cavity by a doctor
options.B: Has a lower risk of residual cholesteatoma
options.C: Allows for easier hearing aid fitting
options.D: The patients are advised not to swim due to the risk of ear infections.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Allows for easier hearing aid fitting Explanation : Canal wall-up procedures do not require routine cleaning of the mastoid cavity and typically allow for easier fitting of hearing aids. Canal Wall Up vs. Canal Wall Down Procedures: Feature Canal Wall Up Canal Wall Down Definition It is a type of mastoidectomy in which the posterior bony canal wall is preserved. This maintains the natural anatomy of the ear canal and middle ear. It is a surgical procedure in which the posterior and superior bony walls of the ear canal are removed. This creates an open cavity that connects the middle ear and mastoid. Recurrence of Disease High rate of recurrence or residual cholesteatoma Low rate of recurrence or residual cholesteatoma (Option B ruled out) Postoperative Care Does not require routine cleaning Requires regular cleaning of the mastoid cavity (once or twice a year) (Option A ruled out) Hearing Rehabilitation Easy to wear a hearing aid, if needed Difficult to fit a hearing aid due to large meatus and mastoid cavity Patient Limitations No limitations to activities like swimming. The patient requires a second-look surgery 6 months later to rule out residual cholesteatoma The patient is advised to not participate in activities like swimming as it can lead to infection of the mastoid cavity. There is no need for second-look surgery. (Option D ruled out) Reference: Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 8th Edition, Page 87 Logan Turner's Diseases of the Nose, Throat and Ear: Head and Neck Surgery, 11th Edition, Page 417

questions.question: A patient presents with a long-standing ear infection characterised by scanty, purulent, foul-smelling discharge and a marginal perforation of the tympanic membrane. The patient also shows signs of a red and fleshy polyp. What is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Atticoantral CSOM Explanation: Atticoantral CSOM is associated with scanty, purulent, foul-smelling discharge, attic or marginal perforations, and shows signs of a red and fleshy polyp and complications like cholesteatoma and granulations. CSOM: Definition and Types: Chronic Suppurative Otitis Media (CSOM): Definition : Long-standing infection of the middle ear cleft, characterised by ear discharge and a permanent perforation in the tympanic membrane. The perforation is considered permanent when covered by squamous epithelium, preventing spontaneous healing. Clinical Classifications Type Description Clinical Features Tubotympanic CSOM (Option A ruled out) Benign or Safe CSOM. Affects the antero-inferior region of the middle ear cleft (eustachian tube and mesotympanum). Profuse, mucoid, odourless discharge Central perforation Pale polyp (if present) Uncommon granulations Rarely associated with cholesteatoma. Rare complications Mild to moderate conductive hearing loss Atticoantral CSOM (Option B) Unsafe or Dangerous CSOM. Affects the posterosuperior region of the middle ear cleft (attic, antrum, and mastoid). Scanty, purulent, foul-smelling discharge Attic or marginal perforation Common granulations due to osteitis Red and fleshy polyp (if present) Frequently associated with cholesteatoma. Common complications Conductive or mixed hearing loss Acute Otitis Media (Option C) generally presents with acute symptoms rather than chronic discharge or perforation. Serous Otitis Media (Option D) : Involves non-infectious fluid in the middle ear, with no perforation or foul-smelling discharge (typical of atticoantral CSOM). Reference: Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 8th Edition, Page 81 Logan Turner's Diseases of the Nose, Throat and Ear: Head and Neck Surgery, 11th Edition, Page 412, 413

questions.question: Which examination method is most effective for visualising a suspected cholesteatoma and assessing the condition of the ossicles in a patient with CSOM?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Examination Under a Microscope Explanation : Examination Under a Microscope provides a detailed view of the middle ear, allowing for visualisation of cholesteatoma, the condition of the ossicles, granulations, and any signs of bone erosion. Examination for Chronic Suppurative Otitis Media (CSOM): Examination Procedure Purpose Examination Under a Microscope (Otomicroscopy) Provides a detailed view compared to an otoscope. (Option A ruled out) Identifies discharge, cholesteatoma, ossicle condition, granulations, and signs of bone erosion. Tuning Fork Tests and Audiogram (Option D ruled out) An audiogram identifies the type and extent of hearing loss (conductive, sensorineural, or mixed). Tuning fork tests (Rinne, Weber, Schwabach) differentiate between conductive and sensorineural hearing loss. Usually, CHL but SNHL may also be present in long-standing cases. X-Ray Mastoids/High-Resolution CT Scan Temporal Bone (Option B ruled out) Determines the extent of bone destruction and mastoid pneumatization. A CT scan helps identify low-lying dura or anteposed sigmoid sinus, relevant for surgical planning. Culture and Sensitivity of Ear Discharge Identifies specific bacteria causing the infection. Guides appropriate antibiotic therapy. Reference: Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 8th Edition, Page 83, 84 Logan Turner's Diseases of the Nose, Throat and Ear: Head and Neck Surgery, 11th Edition, Page 412, 413

questions.question: Which of the following is a Canal wall-down procedure commonly performed in the surgical treatment of Atticoantral Chronic Suppurative Otitis Media (CSOM)?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Modified Radical Mastoidectomy Explanation: Modified Radical Mastoidectomy is a Canal wall-down procedure where the posterior wall of the ear canal is removed to create a single cavity for easier disease eradication and cleaning. Treatment of Chronic Suppurative Otitis Media (CSOM): Tubotympanic CSOM: Medical Treatment : Aural Toilet : Removal of discharge and debris using suction, dry mopping, or irrigation with sterile saline. The ear should be dried thoroughly after irrigation. Ear Drops: Medicated drops (e.g., ciprofloxacin or ofloxacin with steroids) are applied while the patient lies down with the affected ear up. Gentle pressure is given on the tragus after the instillation, to ensure the medication reaches the middle ear. Systemic Antibiotics : Used during acute exacerbations, though not typically needed for chronic cases. Precautions: Avoid water exposure (use earplugs) and avoid forceful nose blowing. Surgical Treatment (if medical therapy fails): Tympanoplasty: Repair of the tympanic membrane and reconstruction of the hearing mechanism. Atticoantral CSOM: Surgical Treatment : Canal Wall Down Procedures : Removes the posterior wall of the ear canal, creating a single cavity. Atticotomy: Incision in the ear canal to remove cholesteatoma from the attic. Modified Radical Mastoidectomy: Removes cholesteatoma and diseased mastoid air cells while preserving the eardrum and ossicles. Radical Mastoidectomy : Rarely performed, involves removing all mastoid air cells and ossicles. Canal Wall-Up Procedures : Preserves the posterior wall of the ear canal. Intact Canal Wall Mastoidectomy : Removes disease through the ear canal and mastoid while keeping the posterior wall intact. Advantages: Dry ear and easier hearing reconstruction, but higher risk of residual cholesteatoma requiring regular follow-ups. Conservative Treatment (for non-surgical candidates): Regular Cleaning : Remove discharge and debris. Topical Medications : Antibiotic ear drops. Polyps and Granulations: Surgically removed with cup forceps or chemically cauterized using agents like silver nitrate or trichloroacetic acid. Monitoring : Regular checkups to assess disease progression and treatment effectiveness. Intact Canal Wall Mastoidectomy (Option A): Also known as a combined approach mastoidectomy, this procedure preserves the posterior bony wall of the ear canal. It offers benefits such as better cosmetic outcomes and potentially easier hearing reconstruction. However, it has a higher risk of residual disease, making it less suitable for complicated cases of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM). Tympanoplasty (Option B): This procedure is focused on reconstructing the eardrum (myringoplasty) and/or the ossicular chain (ossiculoplasty) to enhance hearing. Although it may be combined with mastoidectomy for CSOM treatment, it is not considered a Canal Wall Down (CWD) procedure. Atticotomy (Option D): This procedure involves accessing the attic (epitympanum) to remove diseased tissue. It is less extensive than a modified radical

questions.question: Which of the following describes the characteristic features of inactive squamosal disease in CSOM?

options.A: Presence of cholesteatoma with mucopurulent discharge
options.B: Permanent perforation of the pars tensa with no active inflammation
options.C: The presence of retraction pockets with no active discharge
options.D: Healed tympanic membrane with tympanosclerosis and conductive hearing loss

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Presence of retraction pockets with no active discharge Explanation : The presence of retraction pockets with no active discharge is indicative of inactive squamosal disease, where pockets can collect debris but are not actively discharging. Newer Classification of Chronic Suppurative Otitis Media (CSOM): Mucosal Disease: Affects the mucosal lining of the middle ear cleft. Type Description Active Mucosal Disease Perforation of the pars tensa. Inflammation of the middle ear mucosa. Mucopurulent discharge. Inactive Mucosal Disease (Option B ruled out) Permanent perforation of the pars tensa. Permanent perforation: Fusion of squamous epithelium and mucosa. No active inflammation or discharge. Healed Otitis Media (Option D ruled out) Healed but atrophic tympanic membrane Prone to retraction Tympanosclerosis may be present Conductive hearing loss Squamosal Disease: Involves squamous epithelium in the middle ear cleft. Type Description Active Squamosal Disease (Option A ruled out) Presence of cholesteatoma. Purulent, offensive discharge present. Inactive Squamosal Disease Presence of retraction pockets in the tympanic membrane. No active discharge. But keratin debris in retraction pockets can trigger infection and discharge. Reference: Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 8th Edition, Page 81, 82 Logan Turner's Diseases of the Nose, Throat and Ear: Head and Neck Surgery, 11th Edition, Page413

questions.question: Which of the following is a typical characteristic of tubercular otitis media?

options.B: Multiple perforations of the tympanic membrane
options.C: Sudden onset of symptoms with rapid progression

questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Multiple perforations of the tympanic membrane Explanation: Tubercular otitis media is distinguished by multiple small perforations in the tympanic membrane, which can eventually combine into one larger perforation, making it a key characteristic of the disease. Tubercles form in the submucosal layers of the middle ear, leading to caseation, necrosis of the tympanic membrane, and multiple perforations. It is also associated with painless, foul-smelling ear discharge and facial paralysis. Fig: Multiple perforations of the tympanic membrane Persistent and severe ear pain (Option A): Tubercular otitis media is typically painless , and earache is notably absent in most cases. There is typically painless necrosis of the tympanic membrane. Sudden onset of symptoms with rapid progression (Option C): The onset of tubercular otitis media is slow and insidious , not sudden or rapidly progressing, which is more typical of other types of ear infections like acute otitis media. Mild hearing loss (Option D): Hearing loss in tubercular otitis media is often severe and disproportionate to other symptoms such as ear discharge . It can also include a sensorineural component if the inner ear is affected.

questions.question: A 10-year-old child presents with hearing loss and a retracted tympanic membrane on otoscopic examination. The pars flaccida is completely retracted, and the retraction pocket is fully visible, and the tympanic membrane is in contact with the malleus. According to the Tos & Poulsen classification, what is the appropriate classification for this retraction?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Type II Explanation: Type II: Complete retraction with the tympanic membrane in contact with the malleus, which is the situation described in this case. Tos & Poulsen Classification of Pars Flaccida Retraction Type 0: Normal Pars flacida Type I: Retraction in the direction of the malleus neck but not adherent to it, with a visible airspace behind the pocket (Option B ruled out) Type II: Retraction adherent to the malleus neck, full extent of retraction pocket visible and no visible air space. Type III: Retraction beyond the bony annulus, with or without slight bone resorption, part of the retraction pocket is not visible (Option D ruled out) Type IV: Retraction beyond the malleus neck with definite signs of bony erosion of the annulus. Sadé Classification of Pars Tensa Retraction Stage 1: Mild retraction [The tympanic membrane pars tensa is mildly retracted.] Stage 2: Retraction onto the incus [The tympanic membrane pars tensa is retracted onto the incudostapedial joint,touches the incus.] Stage 3: Retraction onto promontory [The tympanic membrane pars tensa is retracted onto the promontory but not adherent.] Stage 4: Adhesion of pars tensa to medial wall [The tympanic membrane pars tensa is adherent to the medial wall.] Stage 5: Spontaneous perforation with otorrhea and polyp formation [The tympanic membrane is spontaneously perforated with evidence of otorrhea and polyp formation.] Reference: Sades Classification Tos & Poulsen Classification

questions.question: A 30 year old patient with chronic otitis media presents with a perforated tympanic membrane and erosion of the malleus. The surgeon plans to repair the tympanic membrane and place a graft on the remaining malleus. According to Wullstein's classification, which type of tympanoplasty is being performed?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Type I Explanation: Graft placement over the remaining malleus in the presence of a perforated tympanic membrane and erosion of the malleus, as described in this scenario. Tympanoplasty Overview Definition : Surgical procedure for treating conductive hearing loss by eradicating middle ear disease and reconstructing the hearing mechanism. Objective : Restore hearing based on the extent of damage in the ear. Principles of Tympanoplasty: Intact Tympanic Membrane : Essential for amplifying sound transmission through a large hydraulic ratio with the stapes footplate. Ossicular Chain : Conducts sound from the tympanic membrane to the oval window. Two Functioning Windows : Oval Window : Receives sound vibrations. Round Window : Acts as a relief window for cochlear fluid movement. Acoustic Separation of Windows : Prevents sound from reaching both windows simultaneously, achieved through: Intact tympanic membrane. Ossicular chain directing sound primarily to the oval window. Air in the middle ear. Functioning Eustachian Tube : Ensures proper middle ear aeration. Functioning Sensorineural Apparatus : The cochlea and VIIIth nerve must be functional for hearing. Types of Tympanoplasty (Wullstein's Classification): Type Description Type I Myringoplasty: Repair of a perforated tympanic membrane using a graft over the malleus. Type II Graft placed on the incus and perforated tympanic membrane. Type III Graft placed directly on the stapes head in absence of the malleus and incus (myringostapediopexy or columella tympanoplasty). Type IV Graft placed over the footplate of the stapes in the absence of the Malleus, Incus and Stapes suprastructure (cavum minor), allowing sound to act directly on the footplate. Type V Fenestration operation: Creation of a new window on the lateral semicircular canal, creating an alternate pathway for the sound to travel instead of the natural pathway. Type VI Sonoinversion: Graft placed over the round window, reversing the pathway of sound transmission (Sound now travels from Oval window to Round window) Reference: Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 8th Edition, Page 34, 35
